newsitem.title: USA: Dlr slide worsens at US noon on Swiss franc buying.
newsitem.headline: Dlr slide worsens at US noon on Swiss franc buying.

text.p: The dollar continued to weaken in US morning trade as the focus shifted to Swiss franc buying from yen buying and sterling selling overnight, dealers said.
Dealers reported heavy sales of mark/Swiss, which may have had an exaggerated effect on dollar/Swiss with trade thinned by holidays across much of continental Europe.
"People were buying mark/Swiss and that's going to weigh on the dollar. The trade was coming out of Switzerland," said one trader.
The dollar fell to 1.7070/80 marks from 1.7120/30 at the open and 1.4443/53 Swiss francs from 1.4490/00.
The dollar fell as low as 1.7047 marks and 1.4410 Swiss before finding support, steepening its decline from 1.7190/00 marks and 1.4581/86 Swiss at Wednesday's close.
The greenback stood flat at 123.73/83 yen versus 123.72/77 at the open, but well off Wednesday's close at 125.05/10.
Currency players speculated that the Swiss might attract buyers amid talk that European Economic and Monetary Union will include a wide array of participants in its first round.
Sterling on Wednesday got hit by a news report that Labor leaders would reintroduce it to the Exchange Rate Mechanism at a central rate of 2.50 marks, down from about 2.77 now.
The UK Treasury would later deny the report, but the market would continue to sell the pound, which fell another three pfennigs on Thursday.
Rumors flew about the pound, including an apparently bad rumor that new Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown had told a UK radio outlet that sterling was too strong.

"I think it's all rubbish; they have absolutely no intention of going into ERM. But this is a new (UK) government and any slight hint of them doing something unexpected is having a magnified effect," said Chris Iggo, chief economist at BZW Securities.
Sterling/mark stood near its session low of 2.7635 at U.S. midday, well off its overnight high at 2.7914. That helped strengthen the mark against the dollar, dealers said.
"Dollar/mark is coming down on its own, but sterling/mark certainly helped it come down some," said John Hazelton, chief dealer at Manufacturers and Traders Bank.
Dealers expected to see some rebound by sterling soon, with current bargain prices seen too tempting to pass up.
"Sterling got crushed over the last 24 hours and there's some feeling that that move was overdone," said Richard Vullo, vice president at Bayerische Hypothenken und Weschelsbank.
Dollar/yen sat in a narrow U.S. trading range despite hitting a session low when the dollar sold off versus Europe.
A subsequent attempt to rally failed just above 124, where dealers said Asian names had parked a heavy slate of offers.
Sentiment has turned steadily more negative on dollar/yen amid repeated jawboning by Japanese officials and signs of embryonic growth in the beleaguered Japanese economy.

Ministry of Finance currency guru Eisuke Sakakibara sparked dollar sales by noting dollar/yen fluctuated by 23 yen per year on average over the last 10 years, adding that that meant a fall to 103 yen was theoretically possible.
Despite later clarification by the MoF, the dollar failed to recoup its overnight losses.

"The market is very nervous about buying dollars against yen and will continue to be. Japan has achieved what I call 'virtual intervention.' They've managed to achieve a lower dollar without actually spending any forex reserves," Iggo said.
The dollar edged lower to Canadian $1.3823/33 from C41.3831/36. Sterling rose to $1.6198/08 from $1.6153/60.
((--Chris Stetkiewicz, 212-859-1664))
